sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction 2 SO2(g) + O2(g) → 2 SO3(g), given the following standard enthalpy of formation: 
ΔHf° (SO2) = -296.8 kJ/mol, ΔHf° (SO3) = -396.2 kJ/mol.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the given reaction, we can use the equation:

ΔH° = Σ [ΔHf° (products)] - Σ [ΔHf° (reactants)]

For the reaction 2 SO2(g) + O2(g) → 2 SO3(g), we have:

ΔH° = [2 × ΔHf° (SO3)] - [2 × ΔHf° (SO2) + ΔHf° (O2)]

Since O2 is an element in its standard state, its enthalpy of formation is 0 kJ/mol. Therefore, the equation becomes:

ΔH° = [2 × (-396.2 kJ/mol)] - [2 × (-296.8 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = (-792.4 kJ) - (-593.6 kJ)

ΔH° = -198.8 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -198.8 kJ.
